awd_titl_txt: Development of Hydrogeology Experimental System for Radiolabeled Fluid and Colloid Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
This Division of Earth Sciences Instrumentation and Facilities Program grant supports development of a novel experimental system capable of performing Positron emission tomographic (PET) imaging of fluid flow through permeable geologic media.  PET is a technique widely used for cancer research and therapy.  The apparatus would be used to make quantitative measurements of fluid flow in heterogeneous subsurface environments with applications to important scientific questions in hydrogeology, subsurface energy resources, and environmental science. This project will enhance scientific infrastructure for research and education. The enhanced infrastructure will facilitate interdisciplinary research collaborations, with a focus on developing new partnerships with minority serving institutions and regional universities. The experimental system and associated research projects will provide research opportunities that will cultivate full participation of underrepresented demographics in science and higher education.

The system will be capable of safely handling, injecting, imaging, and disposing of pressurized short-lived radiolabeled fluids, gases, and colloids to support multiscale, multiphase flow experiments that will expand existing fluid flow experimental techniques and imaging utilization in hydrogeology and subsurface energy resources research. The experimental apparatus would be mobile and would take advantage of a positron source at the University of Wisconsin’s veterinary school.  Research applications have implications for remediation efforts within contaminated aquifers, efforts to limit nanoparticle contamination of groundwaters, exploration of engineering solutions and ramifications of subsurface CO2 sequestration, and improving efficiency of geothermal energy production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Geoscientists are tasked with understanding complex processes across an range of spatial and temporal scales. One of the greatest challenges facing hydrogeologists is the need to utilize and apply our fundamental mechanistic understanding of pore scale processes to larger-scale natural, environmental, and engineering challenges such as contaminant transport in aquifers, bacteria filtration, and CO2 and hydrogen flow and trapping storage reservoirs. Recent advances in pore-scale imaging methods have led to rapid improvements in understanding of fundamental pore-scale processes. At the larger scale, decades of field scale demonstrations, remediation activities, and energy resource extraction has provided insights into the challenge of modeling and predicting the impact of geologic heterogeneity on fluid flow in these complex natural systems. What is not known is how to apply our ever-increasing fundamental mechanistic understanding of these flow and transport processes at the pore-scale to intrinsically heterogeneous subsurface geologic environments at larger scales.

The overarching goal of this project was to design and construct an experimental platform to enable the collection of unique datasets employing state-of-the-art imaging tools like positron emission tomography (PET) and computed tomography (CT). These datasets are anticipated to address critical knowledge gaps related to flow and transport of solutes, fluids, and colloids in complex geologic media. The experimental system was successfully constructed and continues to collect data that provides unprecedented quantification of processes like contaminant migration and bacteria transport in aquifer materials, and flow, transport, and reactions in fractured rocks.

The project and datasets produced from the new experimental facilities are having widespread broader impacts on STEM education and human resource development in science, engineering, and technology. To date, data has been collected or is currently being collected for both graduate student and undergraduate theses at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and other collaborating universities. The experimental platform is also enabling unique collaborations that transcend disciplinary boundaries with active project including departments such as Medical Physics, Environmental Engineering, Geologic Engineering, and others in Geoscience. The experimental platform is also providing enriching teaching experiences and data for curriculum development. Data collected from the platform have been incorporated into teaching exercises, and these exercises have been organized into a publicly available open-source platform to enable more widespread impact on both undergraduate and graduate education.

This NSF-funded project is not only advancing our fundamental understanding of subsurface flow processes but has also facilitated collaborations, promoted diversity, and enriched educational experiences. The experimental platform stands as a transformative tool, fostering innovation and interdisciplinary research that is key for advancing knowledge of flow and transport processes in geologic systems.
